discussion.content: Goodluck

comments.content: Wish me luck as I'm taking the exam tomorrow morning. My understand here is this, the router needs to have an IP address associated with each VLAN on the trunk, however the router only has one physical interface for the link connected to the VLAN trunk. To solve this, multiple virtual router interfaces, one associated with each VLAN on the trunk is created. These virtual interfaces are called subinterfaces. Got this info from - https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2990405&seqNum=2#:~:text=Routers%20use%20subinterfaces%20as%20the,link%20connected%20to%20the%20trunk.

discussion.content: i wish someone would explain this before i will take my exam next week

questions.question_text: A technician is redesigning a SOHO network on a single router and three switches that are configured in a hierarchical design. The new design must separate the marketing department's large amount of print traffic from the rest of the network. However, it must still allow sharing with the rest of the company. The technician has created a marketing VLAN. Which of the following configurations is necessary to complete the design?

choices.D: A print server to cache files
choices.A: A default VLAN for the rest of the company

discussion.content: Out-of-band (OOB) is a networking term which refers to having a separate channel of communication which does not travel over the usual data stream. Out-of-band management allows the network operator to establish trust boundaries in accessing the management function to apply it to network resources.

questions.question_text: A network technician has been attempting to gain access to a switch over the network after an extended power outage but has been unsuccessful. The technician runs a network scan and does not find the switch in the results. The switch is turned on, and the link lights are all green. Which of the following should the technician use to gain access to the switch?
A network director is creating a document that outlines what employees can and cannot do when they are connected to the corporate VPN. Which of the following is the director creating?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
key word = connected to the corporate VPN

comments.content: Even though you can connect via VPN on site, there's really no point. VPN is mostly use so offsite user can login.

discussion.content: Why is this A? It did not mention anything about users connecting remotely.
Correct answer is A.

comments.content: I was also fools. Below explanations are helpful to understand. Thanks to all.

discussion.content: For those who are confused. I asked to Jason Dion he said the correct answer is 'A'.

It's A. The source IP is the customer. The destination IP in the example is an enterprise-class IP address, so it must be the company's server. Therefore Allow any source IP from any source port to the server using HTTPS (443).

comments.content: You need to make outbound rules for server to send traffic back. Answer can be C, allowing the server to send traffic to any destination IP/port out the network

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A, the source will be the customers, so you have to allow any. and only the destination which is the company's website is needed as well as the 443 port.

Correct answer is A.
If you follow the table they give you then it's
Allow (action) any (src IP) any (src port) 10.5.0.10 (dst IP) 443 (dst port/HTTPS)
This allows any IPs from any ports to connect to the website's IP on HTTPS
A standard ACL is "access-list access-list-number {permit|deny} {host|source source-wildcard|any}"
you defiantly are not about to allow traffic from any when they specifically ask for HTTPS.

I think this is how the firewall should be configured.
Time---------Action---------- -Src IP---------------Scr Port-----Dst IP------Dst Port
 ---------------Allow----------all customers(Any)-----Any-----10.5.0.10-----443 
So, the right option is A.

Now, on the firewall config table, option C ------> “10.5.0.10 443 any any” will look like this.
Time-----------Action-------Src IP---------Scr Port-----Dst IP-------Dst Port
------------------Allow--------10.5.0.10-----443---------Any-----------Any 
Note!! 10.5.0.10 is NOT a source IP address. It is the IP address of the ”company’s secure website” (Dst IP). 
So, option C is INCORRECT

Ahhh sorry, yes it's C. It's a tricky one because remember they're presenting it to you from the attempts, but to configure it is other POV. They can only manage the request the server sends, so they have to configure the server as the source ip to configure the ACL

I think it should be A. They're looking for security, which only allowing traffic from 443 will provide. C is also wrong becasue it allows connections to any port, it's just the opposite of the security they're looking.

If the port 80 on the Destination IP is open that means HTTP traffic flows OK, which also means port 443 needs to be open on that same destination IP to enable secure web browsing. The correct answer is A. Those five digit port numbers are ephemeral (temporary) ports on the end user's machine.
sounds stupid but emulator says C

comments.content: What emulator are you using? I can't see how this rule could possibly work. The rule is allowing HTTPS traffic from the web server to any destination on any port, but it's still blocking all external traffic from accessing the server.
Seems like I need an emulator. Which is best to use?

discussion.content: It Should be 1. The sysntax format is already in the question

comments.content: I think the reason that answer is not D because TACACS+ is Used for device administration. but RADIUS or LDAP are used for network access

discussion.content: Correct answers are A and D

The common use of LDAP is to provide a central place for authentication -- meaning it stores usernames and passwords. LDAP can then be used in different applications or services to validate users with a plugin.

questions.question_text: Which of the following protocols are MOST likely used for enterprise wireless network authentication that is both centralized and secure? (Choose two.)
